Package edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.comp

Class Simplifier

java.lang.Object
edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.comp.Simplifier
public class Simplifier extends Object
First applies any triggers that are satisfied in a problem's initial state and then removes compiled events which can never occur and propositions which are always true or always false from a compiled problem, possibly making it smaller and simpler.

After applying any triggers to the problem's initial state, this compiler creates a heuristic graph initialized on the updated initial state and then extends it until it has leveled off. Heuristic graphs provide a necessary but not sufficient way to detect which propositions must always be true or always false (i.e. when they detect such a proposition they are always correct, but they may not detect every such proposition). A proposition which must always be true is replaced with the constant true; a proposition that can never be true is replaced with the constant false.

Suppose f is a fluent of type entity, and after extending the heuristic graph it is discovered that f can have the values a and b, but can never have the value c. This means that any time a proposition such as f=c appears in a logical expression, it can be replaced with false.

Similarly, suppose f has the value a and can never have and other values. This means that any time a proposition such as f=a appears in a logical expression, it can be replaced with true.

Similarly, if there are any events in the problem whose preconditions can never be true, they are removed from the problem.

Besides possibly making the problem smaller and simpler, this compiler also enables a design pattern where some fluents and triggers are defined to express the initial state of a problem in a convenient way with the knowledge that they will get compiled out later.

For example, consider a problem where characters can walk between locations. They can only walk between certain pairs of locations that are joined by roads, but roads always go in both directions. One could simply list each road twice, like this: 

 entity A : character;
 entity B : location;
 entity C : location;
 property road(from : location, to : location) : boolean;
 property at(character : character) : location;
 road(B, C);
 road(C, B);
 action walk(character : character, from : location, to : location) {
     precondition: at(character) == from & road(from, to);
     effect: at(character) = to;
     consenting: character;
 };
However this can be tedious when there are many roads. An alternative is to use a trigger to ensure that all roads go both ways: 
 trigger road_both_ways(from : location, to : location) {
     precondition: road(from, to) & !road(to, from);
     effect: road(to, from);
 };
This trigger will be applied in the initial state to make roads go both ways, but as long as roads never change, these triggers will never be used again. This compiler will detect that case. It will apply the triggers once in the initial state, remove them, and then replace all atoms referring to a road fluent with either true or false. For example, this ground action: 
 action walk(A, B, C) {
     precondition: at(A) == B & road(B, C);
     effect: at(A) = C;
 };
would be simplified to: 
 action walk(A, B, C) {
     precondition: at(A) == B;
     effect: at(A) = C;
 };
because road(B, C) is always true. Similarly, consider this ground action where the character would walk to a third location D that has no road to B: 
 action walk(A, B, D) {
     precondition: at(A) == B & road(B, D);
     effect: at(A) = D;
 };
Because road(B, D) is always false, this action would get simplified to: 
 action walk(A, B, C) {
     precondition: false;
     effect: at(A) = C;
 };
and removed from the problem alltogether.

There is one important exception to the mechanism that removes impossible actions. Any action which has no consenting characters and whose precondition is originally false (not simplified down to false) will not be removed. Even though a planner could never use an action whose precondition is false when solving a problem, these special actions are preserved as a way for users to impose unexpected changes on a state independently from the planner.

Author:
Stephen G. Ware

    static CompiledProblem
    compile(CompiledProblem problem, Worker.Status status)
    Applies any triggers that are satisfied in the problem's initial state, replaces any propositions which are always true with true and any which are always false with false, and then removes any events which can never occur, creating a new, smaller, simpler problem.

  • Method Details

    • compile

      public static CompiledProblem compile(CompiledProblem problem, Worker.Status status)
      Applies any triggers that are satisfied in the problem's initial state, replaces any propositions which are always true with true and any which are always false with false, and then removes any events which can never occur, creating a new, smaller, simpler problem.
      Parameters:
      problem - the original compiled problem
      status - a status to update while the compiler runs
      Returns:
      a new compiled problem that may have fewer fluent, fewer events, and simpler logical expressions
